terms.definition: Documents that record the objectives, processes, and expected results of software testing, including test plans, test cases, and bug reports.
Quality Assurance - the systematic process of ensuring that software products meet specified requirements and quality standards.
A detailed document that outlines specific testing steps, input data, and expected outcomes to verify software functionality.
A document that records defects found in software systems and provides information on how to reproduce and fix the issues.
A system that tracks and manages changes to documents or code over time, allowing teams to see who made changes and when.
A centralized repository of information and documentation that serves as a single source of truth for teams and users.
Internet of Things - a network of interconnected physical devices that can collect and exchange data over the internet.
A comprehensive document prepared by test managers that outlines the scope, approach, resources, and schedule for testing activities.
A high-level document that describes the overall testing approach, techniques, and processes for a software project.
A set of standardized guidelines that ensure consistency in tone, format, and presentation across all documentation.
Individuals or groups who have an interest in or are affected by a software project, including developers, testers, managers, and end users.
The process of running test cases and recording actual results to verify if software behaves as expected.
Key Performance Indicators - measurable values that demonstrate how effectively objectives are being achieved in testing or business processes.
The systematic process of identifying, recording, and monitoring software bugs throughout their lifecycle from discovery to resolution.
The setup of software and hardware conditions under which testing is performed, including configurations and test data.
